Co-Curricular Record Save Send Feedback [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/2201634] [LINK: https://reports.conestoga.unihub.us/ccr/view] The Student Success Portal’s Events & Activities page gives you access to workshops, clubs, committees, volunteer roles, and recreational opportunities each term, many of which are eligible for Co-Curricular Record (CCR) recognition. How do I find opportunities that I can include on my CCR? From the Events & Activities page, use the search term “CCR” or [LINK: https://successportal.conestogac.on.ca/s/student-engagement/events?descending=false&endorsementIds=3195436&page=1&sortBy=Start&studentSiteId=17] for a list of opportunities eligible for recognition on your Co-Curricular Record. All full-time students also receive the Get Involved Guide each week in their Conestoga inbox with some highlighted opportunities for the upcoming week. How does the CCR support my student experience and my career trajectory? It demonstrates that you are invested in your personal and professional growth. It shows the ways you seek out opportunities for meaningful involvement in the Conestoga community. Helps you develop competencies that will support your personal and professional growth. Helps you write your resume and articulate your learning experiences when applying to jobs, co-op positions, volunteer roles, scholarships, additional post-secondary programs, or any other instances when you may need to demonstrate skills and knowledge gained outside of your academic program. Featured Event [LINK: /students/events/Detail/5111679/ircc-information-session-for-n] In this session for new international students, the following topics will be covered: study permit application process; pre-arrival documents; student and post-graduate work eligibility; and other IRCC-related policies. × Feedback Comments Send Feedback Close

Conestoga College Student Housing Find your home away from home! While studying at Conestoga College, it's important to consider all available housing options, including on and off-campus housing. Conestoga is committed to offering housing options and related services for our students. Please see our [LINK: https://www-assets.conestogac.on.ca/documents/www/about/policies/student-affairs/student-housing-policy.pdf?_gl=1*1htin1v*_gcl_au*OTIxMDU5NDc4LjE3NDEwOTYwNTQ.*_ga*MTY4MDAzMTA4My4xNzM2ODAyMzA1*_ga_RN8C0HR85Y*MTc0MjMwMjY2Ny4xLjEuMTc0MjMxMzYwNC41Ny4wLjEyOTcyODkyNjI.] for more information. Conestoga Housing Brantford - 180 Dalhousie St. Student apartments and suites ideal for students at the Brantford campus. [LINK: https://www.conestogac.on.ca/student-housing/conestoga-housing/brantford-dalhousie-st] Kitchener - 99 Conestoga College Blvd. This residence is ideal for students attending the Kitchener - Doon and Cambridge - Fountain Street campuses. [LINK: https://www.conestogac.on.ca/student-housing/conestoga-housing/kitchener-conestoga-college-blvd] Milton - 1259 Lily Cres. Student apartments and suites ideal for students attending the Milton campuses. [LINK: https://www.conestogac.on.ca/student-housing/conestoga-housing/milton-lily-cres] Waterloo - 60 University Ave. East Student apartments and suites ideal for students attending Waterloo and Kitchener - Downtown campuses. [LINK: https://www.conestogac.on.ca/student-housing/conestoga-housing/waterloo-60-university-ave-east] [LINK: https://www.conestogac.on.ca/student-housing/conestoga-housing/waterloo-60-university-ave-east] Waterloo - 475 King St. North Student apartments and suites ideal for students attending Waterloo and Kitchener - Downtown campuses. [LINK: https://www.conestogac.on.ca/student-housing/conestoga-housing/waterloo-475-king-st-north] [LINK: https://www.conestogac.on.ca/student-housing/conestoga-housing/waterloo-475-king-st-north] Other Rental Resources [LINK: https://conestoga.4stay.com/] To jump-start your search for housing around Conestoga College! For additional off-campus housing, search one of the off-campus rental listing websites or network with family, friends, and other Conestoga College students. [LINK: http://www.places4students.com] [LINK: https://conestoga.4stay.com/] [LINK: https://www.kijiji.ca/] [LINK: http://www.facebook.com/marketplace] [LINK: http://www.padmapper.com] [LINK: http://www.gottarent.com] [LINK: http://www.walkscore.com] More Information Available! Visit our [LINK: https://www.conestogac.on.ca/international/student-support/housing] for resources to search for off campus rentals. These resources are applicable to international and domestic students. Check out the [LINK: https://www-assets.conestogac.on.ca/documents/www/student-housing/your-guide-to-student-living.pdf?_gl=1*i5408r*_gcl_aw*R0NMLjE3NDY3MTg0MTIuQ2owS0NRandyUEhBQmhDSUFSSXNBRlcyWEJOeTZYelVtMGxiSnlBMDY4VWJsdFdlQWNOTFk4anV5ZzNjQ1hmRHgwNG94b3MtVlNCYTlWTWFBdWJrRUFMd193Y0I.*_gcl_au*MTMxMDAyMDM2NS4xNzUxOTAyNjIy*_ga*MTY0NjE3MTUxNS4xNzM0NzE0OTI2*_ga_RN8C0HR85Y*czE3NTIwNzgzMjEkbzIkZzEkdDE3NTIwODM2NTUkajMwJGwwJGgxMDEyOTcxMjkw] for all things related to being a tenant/renter. Register for one of our upcoming [LINK: https://successportal.conestogac.on.ca/s/student-engagement/events?descending=false&page=1&sortBy=Start&studentSiteId=17&text=housing%20wednesdays] to learn about effective strategies for your housing search in Canada. Additional Housing Resources Off-Campus Rentals Live off campus with roommates or on your own. The most common way to search for off-campus housing is through rental listing websites or networking with family, friends, and other Conestoga College students. Visit our [LINK: https://www.conestogac.on.ca/international/student-support/housing] for resources to search for off-campus rentals. These resources are applicable to international and domestic students. Temporary Housing If you do not find a place to live before you arrive in Canada, your option is to book temporary accommodations until you secure longer-term housing. There are hotel and potential residence options for you to explore. Visit the [LINK: https://www.conestogac.on.ca/international/student-support/housing] information for links! Homestay Homestay is a program that matches international students with local host families to live with while studying at Conestoga. Conestoga College partners with Canada Homestay Network Inc. (CHN) to administer our Homestay program. For more information on the Homestay program, visit our [LINK: https://www.conestogac.on.ca/international/student-support/housing ] Housing Search When searching for housing it is important to understand what is required of your search, and what will be required of you when you need to sign a lease. Visit our [LINK: https://www.conestogac.on.ca/international/student-support/housing] (under off-campus rentals), for resources in understanding your Canadian housing search. This information is applicable to both International and Domestic Students. More Ways to Connect If you are an international student and have questions about housing, please email an International Transition Coordinator here: [LINK: mailto:internationaltransition@conestogac.on.ca] If you are a domestic or International Student with questions about Conestoga’s Residence, email [LINK: mailto:mailto:info@conestogaresidence.ca] , and for Conestoga's Off-Campus Housing, email [LINK: mailto:info@conestogaoffcampus.ca] .

Student Ask for Help - Advising Contact Instructions : Please tell us generally about how we can help. Note : Form submissions will be visible to the student and employees supporting student success. Personal information unrelated to the request or of a sensitive nature should not be included on the form . Typical response time: 3 - 7 business days To book an appointment with your Student Success Advisor (SSA) and view their drop-in schedule, visit the [LINK: https://successportal.conestogac.on.ca/students/appointments/app/topic/83?siteId=1] . For concerns about well-being, mental health or behavioural issues, please submit a [LINK: https://studentsuccess.conestogac.on.ca/faculty/careteam] . Student Number (required) Campus Any Brantford Cambridge - Fountain Street Cambridge - Reuter Guelph Ingersoll Skills Training Centre Kitchener - Downtown Kitchener - Doon Milton Stratford Waterloo Program Name (required) Academic Concerns Please indicate the general concerns by selecting from the following list, then specify the scope of the issue in the textbox below. Absences Academic Integrity College not meeting my expectations Co-op, field placement, or hands on learning Deadlines / tests Failing, withdrawing or discontinued Further education after this Interactions with peers in my classes Learning strategies and skills Scheduling issues Understanding college in Canada Registration concerns Other Personal Concerns Your form submission will be reviewed by a member of the Student Success Advising team. When it comes to personal matters, we can assist you with finding the right support to meet your needs. In some cases, that might be general assistance by a member of our team, and in others we may help you connect with a specialist in another department who can go into more detail. If mental health is central to your current situation, please consider a Care Team referral linked above. Career plans and long-term goals Finances, tuition and student fees Housing or living arrangements Job issues or seeking employment Community or sense of belonging Disability or accessibility Health or well-being Interpersonal relationships (friends, roommates, family, etc.) Work permits or study visas Other Additional Information (required) Please provide clarification about your concerns to help us connect you with the appropriate support. For your privacy, do not include sensitive personal information. Save draft Submit

Contact – Student Success Portal For assistance with services on the Student Success Portal , please visit the specific service site from the HOME landing page. Each service will have unique contact information and methods that you can use to reach the service directly with your questions.

Conestoga College collects personal information from students under the legal authority of the Ontario Colleges of Applied Arts and Technology Act and ensures the personal information is managed in compliance with the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act in order offer students a comprehensive program of career-oriented, post-secondary education and training. The purpose of the Student Success Portal is to provide students with one shared system that enables students to self-book appointments with a variety of service teams at the College. As such, service teams will create consultation notes for students to review. These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way. Students participating in Events & Activities are acknowledging the sharing of their information for the purposes of tracking booking, attendance and follow-up activities by college services and opportunity providers. Conestoga protects personal information and only discloses it as required by law. If you have any questions, please reach out to [LINK: mailto:privacy@conestogac.on.ca] . By accepting these terms, you consent to the Student Success Portal and the information sharing provisions within it.

Contact – Student Success Portal For assistance with services on the Student Success Portal , please visit the specific service site from the HOME landing page. Each service will have unique contact information and methods that you can use to reach the service directly with your questions.

Conestoga College collects personal information from students under the legal authority of the Ontario Colleges of Applied Arts and Technology Act and ensures the personal information is managed in compliance with the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act in order offer students a comprehensive program of career-oriented, post-secondary education and training. The purpose of the Student Success Portal is to provide students with one shared system that enables students to self-book appointments with a variety of service teams at the College. As such, service teams will create consultation notes for students to review. These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way. Students participating in Events & Activities are acknowledging the sharing of their information for the purposes of tracking booking, attendance and follow-up activities by college services and opportunity providers. Conestoga protects personal information and only discloses it as required by law. If you have any questions, please reach out to [LINK: mailto:privacy@conestogac.on.ca] . By accepting these terms, you consent to the Student Success Portal and the information sharing provisions within it.

Disability-Related Accommodation Process Save Send Feedback The academic accommodation process is a collaborative effort between students and Accessible Learning. The goal is to reach agreement on appropriate accommodations, ensuring students have equitable access to their education. Faculty may be involved in this process as experts in academic requirements. While we do not share students’ health information with faculty, there are some accommodations where we may need to provide context about the barriers a student encounters in the academic environment to support the process. If students disagree with a decision, they have the right to appeal: As a first step, students should discuss their concerns with their Accessibility Advisor. If a student believes a decision was made in error, they may appeal to the Manager of Accessible Learning. Appeals are reviewed by a person not directly involved in the original decision to ensure fairness. Depending on the situation, appeals may be addressed to the Director of Advising, Accessibility & Testing, or the Dean of Students. If the decision was made by a faculty member, concerns should first be brought to the Program Chair, and if necessary, to the Dean. Students are also encouraged to review the Academic Dispute Resolution and Appeals policy, which outlines additional options for addressing academic concerns. More details can be found on the college’s [LINK: https://mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms/certificate-checker?login=false&originalUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.conestogac.on.ca.mcas.ms%2Fabout%2Fcorporate-information%2Fpolicies%3FMcasTsid%3D20893&McasCSRF=353cc7976f18d7f0a333128d997b2481c56271842b28b8d52bccf1221645da51] . What are assistive technologies? Save Send Feedback [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/2859407] Assistive Technology Overview Students registered with [LINK: https://studentsuccess.conestogac.on.ca/myLearning/AcademicAndTestingAccommodations] have access to many different assistive technologies to support their learning. What is Assistive Technology? Assistive Technology (AT) is any equipment used to increase efficiency, maintain function, or improve the capability of individuals with disabilities. Students use Assistive Technology to research, write, and study more effectively. Examples Text-to-Speech Software: speaks everything on a computer screen, including alternative format textbooks, website text etc. Speech-to-text Software: allows the user to say commands and to enter text using their voice Recording devices: allows the user to capture information presented verbally (i.e.lectures) to review at a later time Frequency Modulation (FM) Systems: transmits an instructor’s voice directly to the student at a constant level, ensuring that the instructor’s voice is heard above the level of background noise Mind-mapping software: allows the user to organize their ideas through web-diagrams and create visual linkages between concepts Word Prediction: predicts words on the basis of the first few letters typed, which allows users to select the required word from a drop down menu Adapted from [LINK: http://www.disabilityissues.ca/english/Link_docs/LDResour.pdf] [LINK: http://www.disabilityissues.ca/english/Link_docs/LDResour.pdf] Assistive Technology Available Our labs are equipped with computers, height-adjustable desks, printers, scanners, software programs and devices to support a wide variety of learning needs. AT available at all Conestoga campuses: Text-to-speech software: Read&Write Speech-to-text: Dragon Naturally Speaking Screen Magnifier: ZoomText Screen reader: JAWS Mind-mapping software: Mindomo Note taking support: Glean, Digital recorders, Smart Pens Alternative keyboards and mice Featured Event [LINK: /students/events/Detail/5192097/important-documents-and-other-] Learn how to apply for important documents such as the Social Insurance Number (SIN) and government-issued photo ID. Discover options for internet and mobile services, how to open a bank account, and how to use public transit to navigate your campus communities. × Feedback Comments Send Feedback Close

Assistive Software Save Send Feedback [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/2866629] Assistive Software We have the following software available at all [LINK: https://lib.conestogac.on.ca/assistive-technology/hours-locations] . Read&Write For reading, writing, studying & research. Download links: [LINK: https://fastdownloads2.texthelp.com/readwrite12/installers/ca/read&write.exe] [LINK: https://fastdownloads2.texthelp.com/readwritemac7/installers/read&write.dmg?_ga=2.10348597.1620579241.1571662788-848083162.1557423867] [LINK: https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/readwrite-for-google-chro/inoeonmfapjbbkmdafoankkfajkcphgd] [LINK: https://microsoftedge.microsoft.com/addons/detail/readwrite-for-microsoft-/bjglhpoliipklkfjcahfefdlfpifcinb] Choose the Microsoft Account option when logging in and use your Conestoga email and password. Read&Write is a literacy toolbar with text-to-speech as well as learning tools to support reading, writing, studying and research within common computer applications. The full version of Read&Write is available for all current Conestoga students and employees to download using the links above. For Read&Write for Chromebooks, iPad, or Android tablets, please [LINK: mailto:at@conestogac.on.ca] . Training Resources: [LINK: https://www.texthelp.com/Uploads/MediaLibrary/texthelp/US-Training-Documents/Read-Write-for-Windows-Quick-Reference-Guide-11-2F2018.pdf] [LINK: https://www.texthelp.com/Uploads/MediaLibrary/texthelp/US-Training-Documents/Read-Write-for-Windows-Quick-Start-Guide-USA-Jan-2019-(1).pdf] [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLvSZbmGbKpCQEi1OB-nu-wA5KexHppO9C] [LINK: https://training.texthelp.com/course/view.php?id=77] (Choose 'Login with Microsoft' and use your Conestoga email address and password) Dragon NaturallySpeaking Dragon NaturallySpeaking is a speech-to-text software program that allows you to turn your voice into text by speaking naturally. Conestoga provides access to the Windows version, but a mobile version is also [LINK: https://www.nuance.com/dragon.html] . Quick links: [LINK: https://www.nuance.com/dragon/support/dragon-naturallyspeaking.html] [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ImlKOA1MhlI] Mindomo Mindomo is a mind-mapping tool that can be used for: Brainstorming Capturing ideas and concepts Organizing written assignments and presentations Time and task management Users can access Mindomo online, as desktop software for Windows & Mac, as well as on Android, Chrome and iOS devices Access to Mindomo is available to students registered with Accessible Learning Services. Please reach out to [LINK: mailto:mailto:AT@conestogac.on.ca] or your Accessible Learning Advisor for more information. Quick links: [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DSnCEXpqi50] [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=83JXkIrc4wM] ZoomText ZoomText Magnifier/Reader is a fully integrated magnification and reading program tailored for low-vision users. Magnifier/Reader enlarges and enhances everything on your computer screen, echoes your typing and essential program activity, and automatically reads documents, web pages, and email. Quick links: [LINK: https://zoomtext.zendesk.com/hc/en-us?_ga=2.264405452.2125255696.1531494935-161026172.1531494935] [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fhLV6ydGqWg] JAWS JAWS (Job Access With Speech) is a screen reader that allows students who are blind or visually impaired to navigate the Internet and most Windows-based applications with a text-to-speech output or by a Refreshable Braille display. Quick links: [LINK: https://www.freedomscientific.com/products/blindness/jawsdocumentation] [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3MUEyYoKwx0] Genio Notes Genio Notes is a recording and notetaking tool. Features: Record your lectures in class and online Add labels and notes Transcribe Compatibility: Chrome browser, Android, and iOS mobile devices Access to Genio Notes is available to students registered with Accessible Learning Services. Please reach out [LINK: mailto:mailto:AT@conestogac.on.ca] or your Accessible Learning Advisor for more information. Built-in Accessibility Features Most devices have powerful accessibility features already built into their operating systems. Our staff can help provide you with support to use your devices more effectively. Mac OS-X and iOS Accessibility Features On an Apple product, go to the "Accessibility" icon under the Settings icon to access the following tools: VoiceOver: screen reader Zoom: magnifier Display Accommodations like Dark mode Assistive Touch Text to Speech Quick links: [LINK: https://www.apple.com/ca/accessibility/mac/] [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLIl2EzNYri0cLtSlZowttih25VnSvWITu] Windows Accessibility Features On a Microsoft product, go to the "Ease of Access Center" in the computer's control panel. The Ease of Access Center provides access to the following tools: Magnifier Narrator: screen reader Windows Speech Recognition On- Screen Keyboard Quick links: [LINK: https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/products/windows-accessibility?os=windows-10] [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xQMCMPbqeq8lity?os=windows-10] Featured Document [LINK: /students/docs/detail/24/interview-process] What to do before, during and after an interview. × Feedback Comments Send Feedback Close

Contact – Student Success Portal For assistance with services on the Student Success Portal , please visit the specific service site from the HOME landing page. Each service will have unique contact information and methods that you can use to reach the service directly with your questions.

Conestoga College collects personal information from students under the legal authority of the Ontario Colleges of Applied Arts and Technology Act and ensures the personal information is managed in compliance with the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act in order offer students a comprehensive program of career-oriented, post-secondary education and training. The purpose of the Student Success Portal is to provide students with one shared system that enables students to self-book appointments with a variety of service teams at the College. As such, service teams will create consultation notes for students to review. These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way. Students participating in Events & Activities are acknowledging the sharing of their information for the purposes of tracking booking, attendance and follow-up activities by college services and opportunity providers. Conestoga protects personal information and only discloses it as required by law. If you have any questions, please reach out to [LINK: mailto:privacy@conestogac.on.ca] . Contact – Student Success Portal For assistance with services on the Student Success Portal , please visit the specific service site from the HOME landing page. Each service will have unique contact information and methods that you can use to reach the service directly with your questions.

Conestoga College collects personal information from students under the legal authority of the Ontario Colleges of Applied Arts and Technology Act and ensures the personal information is managed in compliance with the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act in order offer students a comprehensive program of career-oriented, post-secondary education and training. The purpose of the Student Success Portal is to provide students with one shared system that enables students to self-book appointments with a variety of service teams at the College. As such, service teams will create consultation notes for students to review. These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way. Students participating in Events & Activities are acknowledging the sharing of their information for the purposes of tracking booking, attendance and follow-up activities by college services and opportunity providers. Conestoga protects personal information and only discloses it as required by law. If you have any questions, please reach out to [LINK: mailto:privacy@conestogac.on.ca] . By accepting these terms, you consent to the Student Success Portal and the information sharing provisions within it.

[LINK: /s/student-engagement/Settings] Description is excited to be part of the upcoming Landscape Ontario Touch-A-Truck event hosted by the Landscape Ontario Waterloo Chapter — and we’d love your help to make it a success! This free, family-friendly event gives children the chance to explore and interact with a wide variety of trucks and vehicles. With over 800 families expected, it’s a fantastic opportunity to connect with our community and share the KidsAbility story. We’re looking for volunteers to represent KidsAbility at our table. What’s involved in this volunteer role: Set up and take down the KidsAbility table (tablecloth, banner and swag will be provided) While standing/sitting at the KidsAbility table, you will share information about our programs and services (materials provided) Engage with families and attendees Spread smiles and high-fives! Available Shifts: Shift 1 8:45 a.m. – 12:00 p.m. 8:45 a.m. –  9:00 a.m. – Set up tablecloth, banner, promotional materials, and swag 9:00 a.m. – 12:00 p.m. – Staff the KidsAbility table and chat with attendees Shift 2 12:00 p.m. –  3:00 p.m. 12:00 p.m. – 2:45 p.m. – Staff the KidsAbility table and chat with attendees 2:45 p.m. – to 3:00 p.m. – Pack up the table tablecloth, banner, and remaining promotional materials, and swag Event Details: Date: Saturday, July 26, 2025 Time: 8:45 a.m. – 3:00 p.m. (Quiet Hour: 9:00 a.m. – 10:00 a.m.) Location: Kitchener Memorial Auditorium – Parking Lot G Rain or Shine – Let’s hope for sunshine! ☀️ Why Volunteer? Be part of an inclusive, community-driven event Support KidsAbility and local families Gain volunteer hours and event experience Enjoy a day of fun, food trucks, and firetrucks! Volunteer as a Peer Leader with SHORE Centre's "Talk Differently" program An innovative project to address gender-based violence and the barriers newcomers and marginalized groups face in accessing reproductive healthcare. Off-Campus Opportunities SHORE Centre, Kitchener, Ontario, Canada Save activity Details Organization: SHORE Centre – Newcomer Educational Program Program Duration: 6–8 weeks (Fall & Winter sessions) Honorarium: $300 per peer leader( 2-3 hours/week) Program Overview: The Talk Differently Project is an innovative initiative to address gender-based violence (GBV) and the barriers newcomers and marginalized groups face in accessing reproductive healthcare. Through a community-led, peer-driven model, this program promotes healthier relationships, equitable attitudes, and systemic change. The program is rooted in the Kitchener-Waterloo region and supports individuals by raising awareness of reproductive health resources and how to access them. Peer Leaders will be trained to create a welcoming, supportive, and educational atmosphere to facilitate workshops for participants from diverse backgrounds. More details in the attached position description! Roller Skating in the Square Join Retro Rollers Inc. on Monday nights for free, adventurous family fun outside Kitchener City Hall! All skill levels are welcome. This community-focused event is intended to be a fun, casual, recreational program. Skate at your own risk. Off-Campus Opportunities 200 King Street West - Carl Zehr Square, Kitchener, Ontario, Canada Save activity Details Join Retro Rollers Inc. on Monday nights for free, adventurous family fun outside Kitchener City Hall! All skill levels are welcome. This community-focused event is intended to be a fun, casual, recreational program. Attendees must accept that skaters of all levels may be on the rink simultaneously. Skate at your own risk. To manage the crowds, there may be a limit to how many people can be on the rink. DJ PDK and others will spin all night to keep you grooving, so grab a friend and your skates and get ready to roller disco dance the night away! No skates? No problem! Skate rentals are available for a rental fee. Kids and Adult skate sizes are available. Socks are required. Bring your own or buy a pair on-site. Don't forget safety gear! Helmets are encouraged. Dates: Monday nights from May to September Event Time: 7pm - 10pm Location: Carl Zehr Square, 200 King Street West, Downtown Kitchener Free to Skate! Skate rentals available for a fee. Review the Rink Rules: 1. Skate at your own risk. 2. No skating while intoxicated. 3. Wear safety equipment. 4. Enter and exit the rink with caution. 5. Skate in a counterclockwise direction. 6. No stopping on the rink. 7. No food or drink on the rink. 8. Refrain from carrying children on the rink. 9. Faster skaters to the outside lane. 10. Extreme speed/racing while roller skating is not permitted. Have fun! PARKING: Downtown surface lots are free after 5pm and on weekends. Find the nearest lot at [LINK: https://www.kitchener.ca/en/parking/find-a-place-to-park.aspx?fbclid=IwZXh0bgNhZW0CMTAAYnJpZBExQkJqekxLaHhmRWRBbFg5VAEeKH3h4h8leg0xYRC7HF42_QaXpJYbfJwPXRWyVq6UbK0YS-00qIXCm6mIues_aem_21RqoglhY9aj8Kh257KBJg] Brought to you by Downtown Kitchener and Retro Rollers Inc. *Student Engagement shares information with students about off-campus co-curricular opportunities to support their social and professional development. Victim Services of Waterloo Region - Volunteer Crisis Responder Crisis Responders are responsible for immediate, mobile response to requests from emergency and police services within Waterloo Region. Volunteer duties include the provision of short-term emotional support and assistance to victims of crime, trauma, or other tragic circumstances. Volunteer Opportunities Victim Services Waterloo Region, Kitchener/Waterloo, Ontario, Canada Save activity Details Looking to gain valuable volunteer experience? Want to give back to your community in a meaningful way? Come volunteer with us at Victim Services of Waterloo Region. Crisis Responders are responsible for immediate, mobile response to requests from emergency and police services within Waterloo Region. Volunteer duties include the provision of short-term emotional support and assistance to victims of crime, trauma, or other tragic circumstances. Crisis Responders also provide service by telephone and ensure appropriate options and/or referrals are available to victims. Volunteers are to conduct themselves and perform duties in accordance with the policies and procedures of Victim Services Waterloo Region. Position Requirements: •Must live in Waterloo Region. •Must be willing to commit to one year of service. •Must be willing to commit to a minimum of four shifts per month. •Must be willing to attend regular Volunteer meetings. •Must possess a valid driver’s licence, liability insurance and reliable transportation. •Must successfully complete an interview, reference and criminal records check, online learning modules, as well as the 60hour volunteer training program. •Must be nineteen years of age or older. •Must be capable of maintaining confidentiality. •Must be able and willing to work as a team member. •Must have problem solving skills. •The ability to speak an additional language is a definite asset. •Must commit to 4 eight-hour ON CALL shifts/month. The duties of a Crisis Responder include: •Participate in 4 eight hour shifts per month. •Respond immediately to requests from police or other emergency personnel by attending on site, at an alternative location, or by telephone as appropriate. •Provide emotional support and assistance to each victim as needed. •Arrange for transportation and/or shelter as needed. •Assist victim in identifying immediate and long-term needs. Provide information, referrals and advocacy as necessary. •Follow-up with victims after initial contact to provide further support, determine status, and identify any further assistance which may be required. If you’re ready to make an impact, visit us online at [LINK: http://www.vswr.ca/volunteer] and fill out an application form or email us at vswr@wrps.on.ca to request a form. * Student Engagement shares information with students about off-campus co-curricular opportunities to support their social and professional development. Discontinuance and Reapplying Save Send Feedback The college will discontinue students who have a Term Weighted Average of less than 49.99% (for most programs) or have failed to clear probation after two consecutive terms. However, students should refer to their [LINK: https://www.conestogac.on.ca/handbook/student-guide#appendices] for program specific requirements. Discontinued students are ineligible to register in their original Program of Studies for a minimum of one term. They can apply to another college program, if it doesn’t share a common platform to the program they were discontinued from. If a student wants to return to their original program after the discontinuance period, they must apply for re-admission. Please see the [LINK: https://www.conestogac.on.ca/policies/discontinuance-procedure] and [LINK: https://www.conestogac.on.ca/policies/readmission-procedure] for more information. Disability-Related Accommodation Process Save Send Feedback The academic accommodation process is a collaborative effort between students and Accessible Learning. The goal is to reach agreement on appropriate accommodations, ensuring students have equitable access to their education. Faculty may be involved in this process as experts in academic requirements. While we do not share students’ health information with faculty, there are some accommodations where we may need to provide context about the barriers a student encounters in the academic environment to support the process. If students disagree with a decision, they have the right to appeal: As a first step, students should discuss their concerns with their Accessibility Advisor. If a student believes a decision was made in error, they may appeal to the Manager of Accessible Learning. Appeals are reviewed by a person not directly involved in the original decision to ensure fairness. Depending on the situation, appeals may be addressed to the Director of Advising, Accessibility & Testing, or the Dean of Students. If the decision was made by a faculty member, concerns should first be brought to the Program Chair, and if necessary, to the Dean. Students are also encouraged to review the Academic Dispute Resolution and Appeals policy, which outlines additional options for addressing academic concerns. More details can be found on the college’s [LINK: https://mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms/certificate-checker?login=false&originalUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.conestogac.on.ca.mcas.ms%2Fabout%2Fcorporate-information%2Fpolicies%3FMcasTsid%3D20893&McasCSRF=353cc7976f18d7f0a333128d997b2481c56271842b28b8d52bccf1221645da51] . [LINK: https://successportal.conestogac.on.ca/s/accessiblelearning] Featured Video [LINK: /students/Videos/detail/22/review-method-of-long-division] This video explains how to use long division. Contact – Student Success Portal For assistance with services on the Student Success Portal , please visit the specific service site from the HOME landing page. Each service will have unique contact information and methods that you can use to reach the service directly with your questions.

Conestoga College collects personal information from students under the legal authority of the Ontario Colleges of Applied Arts and Technology Act and ensures the personal information is managed in compliance with the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act in order offer students a comprehensive program of career-oriented, post-secondary education and training. The purpose of the Student Success Portal is to provide students with one shared system that enables students to self-book appointments with a variety of service teams at the College. As such, service teams will create consultation notes for students to review. These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way. Students participating in Events & Activities are acknowledging the sharing of their information for the purposes of tracking booking, attendance and follow-up activities by college services and opportunity providers. Conestoga protects personal information and only discloses it as required by law. If you have any questions, please reach out to [LINK: mailto:privacy@conestogac.on.ca] . By accepting these terms, you consent to the Student Success Portal and the information sharing provisions within it.

Contact – Student Success Portal For assistance with services on the Student Success Portal , please visit the specific service site from the HOME landing page. Each service will have unique contact information and methods that you can use to reach the service directly with your questions.

Conestoga College collects personal information from students under the legal authority of the Ontario Colleges of Applied Arts and Technology Act and ensures the personal information is managed in compliance with the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act in order offer students a comprehensive program of career-oriented, post-secondary education and training. The purpose of the Student Success Portal is to provide students with one shared system that enables students to self-book appointments with a variety of service teams at the College. As such, service teams will create consultation notes for students to review. These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way. Students participating in Events & Activities are acknowledging the sharing of their information for the purposes of tracking booking, attendance and follow-up activities by college services and opportunity providers. Conestoga protects personal information and only discloses it as required by law. If you have any questions, please reach out to [LINK: mailto:privacy@conestogac.on.ca] . By accepting these terms, you consent to the Student Success Portal and the information sharing provisions within it.

Contact – Student Success Portal For assistance with services on the Student Success Portal , please visit the specific service site from the HOME landing page. Each service will have unique contact information and methods that you can use to reach the service directly with your questions.

Conestoga College collects personal information from students under the legal authority of the Ontario Colleges of Applied Arts and Technology Act and ensures the personal information is managed in compliance with the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act in order offer students a comprehensive program of career-oriented, post-secondary education and training. The purpose of the Student Success Portal is to provide students with one shared system that enables students to self-book appointments with a variety of service teams at the College. As such, service teams will create consultation notes for students to review. These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way. Students participating in Events & Activities are acknowledging the sharing of their information for the purposes of tracking booking, attendance and follow-up activities by college services and opportunity providers. Conestoga protects personal information and only discloses it as required by law. If you have any questions, please reach out to [LINK: mailto:privacy@conestogac.on.ca] . By accepting these terms, you consent to the Student Success Portal and the information sharing provisions within it.

Conestoga College collects personal information from students under the legal authority of the Ontario Colleges of Applied Arts and Technology Act and ensures the personal information is managed in compliance with the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act in order offer students a comprehensive program of career-oriented, post-secondary education and training. The purpose of the Student Success Portal is to provide students with one shared system that enables students to self-book appointments with a variety of service teams at the College. As such, service teams will create consultation notes for students to review. These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way. Students participating in Events & Activities are acknowledging the sharing of their information for the purposes of tracking booking, attendance and follow-up activities by college services and opportunity providers. Conestoga protects personal information and only discloses it as required by law. If you have any questions, please reach out to [LINK: mailto:privacy@conestogac.on.ca] . Student Rights & Responsibilities FAQs Save Send Feedback Who do I contact if I have an emergency or safety concern? If you feel unsafe or need immediate attention on-campus, contact [LINK: https://www.conestogac.on.ca/safety-and-security/contact] . If you are off campus, contact emergency services by calling 911. If you are in crisis and need urgent mental health support, the following resources can help: Suicide Crisis Helpline (all of Canada): 988 HERE 24/7 (Kitchener, Waterloo, Cambridge, Guelph):1-844-437-3247 Good 2 Talk (Post-secondary student helpline): 1-866-925-5454 or text GOOD2TALKON to 686868 Crisis Support Peel (Mississauga, Brampton, Peel areas): 1-888-811-2222 Who can report a Student Rights and Responsibilities Violation? College students, employees, faculty, and members of the public may submit reports or reach out to our email. Can I make a report anonymously? Yes, we accept anonymous reports. Note that this can limit our responses available. If we do not know who you are, we will be unable to follow-up with any updates or next steps on our process. To submit an anonymous report, complete the report form leaving the reporter name and contact information blank. If you would like some follow-up, you can provide an anonymous email address for us to contact. In some cases, we can keep reporters anonymous to other parties involved. If at any point in our process you choose to be anonymous after contacting our office, let us know. We will provide guidance on what that will look like moving forward. What are my options when making a report? The options we will provide you will depend on what the report or concerns are about. We will provide you with the most appropriate information and policies related to your concerns. In some cases, we may connect you with other departments better suited to support you. How do I schedule a meeting with you? We ask that you first reach out to us via email or the report form with additional information on your concerns. This helps us better determine if we are the most appropriate resource for your inquiry. If we can provide further support, we will then share arrange a meeting with a member of our team via email. I’ve received an email from SRR about an incident, what happens next? Follow the instructions outlined in the emails from our office; there may be action items for you to follow. We recommend that you address it as soon as possible. Respond to the email with any questions or concerns you may have. If you received an email with a request to meet, its because we want to hear from you to gather your perspective. A meeting with our office is your opportunity to share your side of events and work on finding a resolution. How do I prepare for a meeting? We understand that connecting with our office can be overwhelming. Here’s some tips to help you feel ready: Review our policies and procedures so you know what to expect. Collect any important documentation like emails, text messages, screen captures, etc. You can send these to us before the meeting or bring them with you. If applicable, write down the names and contact information of any witnesses or other people involved. Make a timeline of events pr notes to help you remember details during the meeting. Consider if you want to bring a support person such as a family member, peer, or advisor. They can take notes and help be there as a moral support. Prepare any questions you have about the policies, procedures, outcome, etc. How do I challenge a decision made by SRR? The challenge process is outlined on page 6 of the [LINK: https://www-assets.conestogac.on.ca/documents/www/about/policies/student-affairs/student-rights-and-responsibilities-procedure.pdf] If you want to challenge a decision that does not affect your academic status, email [LINK: mailto:srr@conestogac.on.ca] and outline your grounds for appeal. The Director of Student Rights and Responsibilities will review it. Appropriate grounds for submitting a challenge are personal bias, unfair treatment or new information. Attach any documents any supporting documentation. If the decision does affect your academic status, submit a formal appeal form as outlined in Step 4 of the [LINK: https://www-assets.conestogac.on.ca/documents/www/about/policies/academic-administration/academic-dispute-resolution-and-appeal-procedure.pdf] (pdf). You can find the form on the student portal under the Services tab, then click "Forms" in the Students in Full-time Programs section. Complete the Student Appeals Form on Laserfiche. Are my conversations with the SRRO confidential? Your conversations with the SRRO are private unless we believe you or someone else is at risk of harm. We won't act on your concerns without your permission unless there's an immediate risk. If we contact you because of a report, we may share some information with involved parties. All records are kept secure according to privacy laws. [LINK: https://www.ontario.ca/document/freedom-information-and-protection-privacy-manual/chapter-5-exemptions-and-exclusions] are records under statutes that expressly state that they prevail over FIPPA. Will SRR violations be visible on my permanent academic record? SRRO decisions and sanctions do not form part of a student's academic record except in cases of long-term suspension or discontinuance from the college. How long does it take to resolve an issue? We typically respond within 2 business days. Time to resolve an issue will depend on the concern, but we will try to move as quickly as possible and will keep you updated on timelines. Contact – Student Success Portal For assistance with services on the Student Success Portal , please visit the specific service site from the HOME landing page. Each service will have unique contact information and methods that you can use to reach the service directly with your questions.

Conestoga College collects personal information from students under the legal authority of the Ontario Colleges of Applied Arts and Technology Act and ensures the personal information is managed in compliance with the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act in order offer students a comprehensive program of career-oriented, post-secondary education and training. The purpose of the Student Success Portal is to provide students with one shared system that enables students to self-book appointments with a variety of service teams at the College. As such, service teams will create consultation notes for students to review. These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way. Students participating in Events & Activities are acknowledging the sharing of their information for the purposes of tracking booking, attendance and follow-up activities by college services and opportunity providers. Conestoga protects personal information and only discloses it as required by law. If you have any questions, please reach out to [LINK: mailto:privacy@conestogac.on.ca] . By accepting these terms, you consent to the Student Success Portal and the information sharing provisions within it.

Discontinuance and Reapplying Save Send Feedback The college will discontinue students who have a Term Weighted Average of less than 49.99% (for most programs) or have failed to clear probation after two consecutive terms. However, students should refer to their [LINK: https://www.conestogac.on.ca/handbook/student-guide#appendices] for program specific requirements. Discontinued students are ineligible to register in their original Program of Studies for a minimum of one term. They can apply to another college program, if it doesn’t share a common platform to the program they were discontinued from. If a student wants to return to their original program after the discontinuance period, they must apply for re-admission. Please see the [LINK: https://www.conestogac.on.ca/policies/discontinuance-procedure] and [LINK: https://www.conestogac.on.ca/policies/readmission-procedure] for more information. Featured Document [LINK: /students/docs/detail/39/working-part-time-when-you-are] When you are looking for part-time work it is important to find something that will allow you to prioritize your studies. This resource discusses typical part-time student jobs, jobs on campus and common methods for searching for part-time work. × Feedback Comments Send Feedback Close

Learning Plan and Learning Contract Save Send Feedback A Learning Plan is a document developed between a student on [LINK: https://www.conestogac.on.ca/admissions/registrar-office/grading-transcripts#:~:text=first%20probation%20(p1)] and a Student Success Advisor and is used to plan strategies that will support a student’s success. A Learning Contract is a formal agreement between the College and a student on [LINK: https://www.conestogac.on.ca/admissions/registrar-office/grading-transcripts#:~:text=second%20probation%20(p2)] outlining specific achievement requirements for the student. Learning Contracts are required when students are on probation for a second time. Students on probation will receive an email from the Office of the Registrar to initiate the Learning Plan or Learning Contract process. Featured Document [LINK: /students/docs/detail/178/job-fair-preparation] Job Fairs can be stressful. Learn what you can do before, during and after a job fair to make the best impression possible. × Feedback Comments Send Feedback Close

Repeating Courses Save Send Feedback Students may attempt a course 2 times. A student wishing to register for a third time must have approval from the Academic Administrator with academic responsibility for the program. Please see Part 4: “Repeated Courses” in the for more information. × Feedback Comments Send Feedback Close

Contact – Student Success Portal For assistance with services on the Student Success Portal , please visit the specific service site from the HOME landing page. Each service will have unique contact information and methods that you can use to reach the service directly with your questions.

Conestoga College collects personal information from students under the legal authority of the Ontario Colleges of Applied Arts and Technology Act and ensures the personal information is managed in compliance with the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act in order offer students a comprehensive program of career-oriented, post-secondary education and training. The purpose of the Student Success Portal is to provide students with one shared system that enables students to self-book appointments with a variety of service teams at the College. As such, service teams will create consultation notes for students to review. These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way. Students participating in Events & Activities are acknowledging the sharing of their information for the purposes of tracking booking, attendance and follow-up activities by college services and opportunity providers. Conestoga protects personal information and only discloses it as required by law. If you have any questions, please reach out to [LINK: mailto:privacy@conestogac.on.ca] . By accepting these terms, you consent to the Student Success Portal and the information sharing provisions within it.

Before Your Assessment Save Send Feedback Students      should arrive 15-minutes before their test start time to secure personal      items and complete check-in. Testing      appointments may be cancelled if students arrive more than 20-minutes late      from the indicated start time. Present      a non-expired physical photo ID (OneCard or government-issued      ID). Only      items required for the assessment will be permitted in the testing      room. All      electronical devices not required for the assessment (smart devices,      phones, tablets) must be turned off and placed in a locker or designated      area provided by the Test Centre (approved accommodations excepted). All      personal items (coats, hats, bags) are to be secured in a locker or      designated area provided by the Test Centre. To      maintain a quiet and controlled testing environment for all test takers,      children are not permitted within the Test Centre and cannot be left      unattended while any student is writing. All      computer-based tests at the Test Centre will be conducted on assigned      desktop computers. Students may use their personal laptops only if the      Test Centre desktop computers do not meet the test requirements or if      specified by the faculty. It is recommended to have your laptop on campus      and fully charged in case it is needed to complete the test.  Please      note the Test Centres may not have power outlets for laptops. To      ensure a comfortable and healthy environment for everyone, Test Centres      are a designated scent-free zone. We kindly request that all individuals      refrain from wearing or using scented products. Only      water is permitted in the testing room (approved accommodations      excepted). Featured Document [LINK: /students/docs/detail/279/student-mental-health-policy] Conestoga College Institute of Technology and Advanced Learning (Conestoga) is committed to cultivating a supportive teaching, learning, living and working environment that addresses the health and wellness needs of our students. × Feedback Comments Send Feedback Close

During Your Assessment Save Send Feedback Students      are expected to follow direction of Test Centre staff. Students      can only communicate with Testing Centre staff. Staff cannot give any      guidance or answer questions regarding test/exam content. Faculty      will not be present in the Test Centre; however, students can request that      Test Centre staff to attempt to contact their faculty for clarifying      questions. Students      can request the use of blank scrap paper from Test Centre staff. All      testing materials must be returned to Test Centre staff at the end of the      test. It      is recommended that students use the washroom before their assessment.      Washroom breaks during assessments will only be permitted if a Test Centre      staff member is available (approved accommodations excepted). In      case of emergency (fire alarm, lockdown), students are to follow the      instructions of the Test Centre staff. The      Test Centre staff will adhere to the guidelines established by the [LINK: https://library.conestogac.on.ca/academic-integrity] department in the event of an academic integrity      breach. Featured Event [LINK: /students/events/Detail/5192087/social-insurance-number-for-in] A Service Canada representative will share key information for international students about Social Insurance Number (SIN) eligibility, how to apply, protect the SIN, and access resources. Students will have opportunity to ask questions. × Feedback Comments Send Feedback Close

After Your Assessment Save Send Feedback Test      Centre staff will submit all completed papers to your faculty. Any      concerns regarding the outcome of an assessment should be discussed with      the student’s faculty. If      applicable, return the locker key to the designated area after gathering your      belongings. Featured Document [LINK: /students/docs/detail/44/job-offer] Negotiating a job offer can be stressful and intimidating. This resource provides some helpful tips for negotiating an offer of employment. × Feedback Comments Send Feedback Close

Contact – Student Success Portal For assistance with services on the Student Success Portal , please visit the specific service site from the HOME landing page. Each service will have unique contact information and methods that you can use to reach the service directly with your questions.

Conestoga College collects personal information from students under the legal authority of the Ontario Colleges of Applied Arts and Technology Act and ensures the personal information is managed in compliance with the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act in order offer students a comprehensive program of career-oriented, post-secondary education and training. The purpose of the Student Success Portal is to provide students with one shared system that enables students to self-book appointments with a variety of service teams at the College. As such, service teams will create consultation notes for students to review. These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way. Students participating in Events & Activities are acknowledging the sharing of their information for the purposes of tracking booking, attendance and follow-up activities by college services and opportunity providers. Conestoga protects personal information and only discloses it as required by law. If you have any questions, please reach out to [LINK: mailto:privacy@conestogac.on.ca] . By accepting these terms, you consent to the Student Success Portal and the information sharing provisions within it.

Understanding Math Anxiety Save Send Feedback [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/1470053] Understanding math anxiety Math anxiety is more than just disliking math. Sometimes you may feel: Fear of making mistakes, lack of confidence in math. Fast heart beating, sweatiness, nausea when anticipating or engaging in math tasks. Wanting to quit when confused or making mistakes in math. Stress before evaluations such as tests, quizzes and exams. Nervous before math class. Procrastination of math homework or assignments. Unable to concentrate on a math task. Does math anxiety affect math ability? The video below explains more about what math anxiety is and does to your brain when you're experiencing it. Math anxiety and working memory Our working memory is a system in our brain responsible for temporarily storing and manipulating information and is essential when solving most math problems. Our working memory can store very limited amounts of information. The amount of information our working memory can store at one time is sometimes referred to a s cognitive load. When our cognitive load has reached its maximum capacity, we stop processing information. Elevated levels of anxiety can affect working memory, decreasing its efficiency. This is not permanent and only occurs for the duration of time that the anxiety lasts. Since math requires working memory, trying to do math under high levels of anxiety can at times feel impossible. So what does this mean? Anxiety can affect math performance no matter how good someone is at math. Our math skills may be just fine and we need to tackle the anxiety! When we learn to reduce the anxiety we feel when doing or anticipating math tasks, our working memory can process information much more easily and efficiently, making things seem more manageable. Myths about math Math comes with its stereotypes. Here are three things that are not true about math: People of different race and sex have varying innate math ability There is a best way to solve a math problem You have to have a 'math brain' to understand math Debunking math stereotypes can shed some positive light on the subject and our ability to improve our math skills. The next time you hear someone say any of the things above, remember they are not true! Strategies for overcoming and managing math anxiety The following strategies are things you can start doing today to help manage and overcome math anxiety. This list is not exhaustive and some things may work better for some people than others. There is no particular order in which you have to follow the strategies. Try whichever ones resonate best with you! Strengthen foundational math knowledge Math builds on itself. Imagine trying to calculate 5+7−4 without knowing how addition or subtractions works. This would be extremely difficult and could lead to things like lack of confidence, defeat, and frustration. Having strong foundational knowledge of the prerequisite skills needed for the math you are required to do will make things easier. When you attempt to solve a math problem without the required foundational knowledge, your working memory can become overloaded. Cognitive load is the amount of information that can be stored in working memory at one time. The weaker your foundational math knowledge is, the more resources are taken up in working memory when solving a math problem, increasing cognitive load and leaving fewer brain resources for the steps required to solve the problem at hand. With a stronger math foundation, more working memory resources can be allocated to solving the problem at hand, and less on trying to understand the basics at the same time. The stronger our basics, the more math confidence you can build. Not sure what foundational knowledge you need to strengthen? [LINK: https://successportal.conestogac.on.ca/students/infopages/detail/9] Find math learning strategies that work for you On the [LINK: https://successportal.conestogac.on.ca/students/infopages/detail/9] you can find a list of math learning strategies you can try. You can keep track of the strategies you have used in a [LINK: https://successportal.conestogac.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/157] . Not all math learning strategies will work for everyone. It is important that you find the ones that work for you. Implementing a math learning strategy will improve understanding, help to develop skills and increase confidence. More learning and study strategies can be found on the [LINK: https://successportal.conestogac.on.ca/s/learningstudyskills] Regular math practice Practicing math by solving math problems is essential to gaining stronger math understanding. [LINK: https://mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms/certificate-checker?login=false&originalUrl=http%3A%2F%2Fuweb.cas.usf.edu.mcas.ms%2F~drohrer%2Fpdfs%2FHartwig_et_al_2022JEPA.pdf%3FMcasTsid%3D20892&McasCSRF=66ad11c9b90ec82b03a3b876260eab4bbb9c2745dd88156ac77b83d00c4997ea] show that spacing out math practice over a period of time rather than completing it all-at-once helps knowledge retention. Diaphragm breathing Diaphragm breathing is a breathing technique that engages the diaphragm (a muscle at the base of our lungs and heart). This breathing technique can help to calm us by lowering heartbeat and stabilizing blood pressure (Learning Diaphragmatic Breathing, 2016) The video below is a demonstration of how to breath with your diaphragm: More math anxiety resources: [LINK: https://mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms/certificate-checker?login=false&originalUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fsuccessportal.conestogac.on.ca.mcas.ms%2Fstudents%2Fvideos%2Fdetail%2F20%3FMcasTsid%3D20892&McasCSRF=66ad11c9b90ec82b03a3b876260eab4bbb9c2745dd88156ac77b83d00c4997ea] to benefit your academic and personal growth. Download this [LINK: https://mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms/certificate-checker?login=false&originalUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fsuccessportal.conestogac.on.ca.mcas.ms%2Fstudents%2Fdocs%2FDetail%2F94%3FMcasTsid%3D20892&McasCSRF=66ad11c9b90ec82b03a3b876260eab4bbb9c2745dd88156ac77b83d00c4997ea] on embracing failure. [LINK: https://mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms/certificate-checker?login=false&originalUrl=https%3A%2F%2Ftlp-lpa.ca.mcas.ms%2Fmath%2Fanxiety%3FMcasTsid%3D20892&McasCSRF=66ad11c9b90ec82b03a3b876260eab4bbb9c2745dd88156ac77b83d00c4997ea] References Learning diaphragmatic breathing. (2016, March 10). Harvard Health. Math learning and study strategies Save Send Feedback [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/1467736] Not sure what areas of math you need help with? Use the [LINK: https://tlp-lpa.ca/math/self-assessments] to find out. Math learning strategies Make sure you are comfortable with the foundational math topics, including: Whole number operations (addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, square root) Fraction operations Reducing fractions (proper, improper, mixed numbers) Decimal operations and place value Order of operations Percent Ratios, rates and proportions A great way to improve your learning is to start thinking about your thinking. Check out this [LINK: https://successportal.conestogac.on.ca/students/videos/detail/13] on starting to think about your thinking and save this [LINK: https://successportal.conestogac.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/91] to look back on during your semester. College classes are much different than high school. This video will walk you through [LINK: http://wolczuk.com/lil.html] . You can also save this [LINK: https://successportal.conestogac.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/92] to bring with you to class. Learning math online and in person can be different. This video will show you [LINK: https://successportal.conestogac.on.ca/students/videos/detail/14] . Check out these tips to improve math learning : Complete homework/practice questions Check your work after you have solved a problem and fix your mistakes right away (so you do not repeat them) Re-do example problems from class independently Re-do problems from tests and assignments that were wrong Re-watch class recordings (if available) Ask questions during class when things are unclear Ask the instructor questions outside of class when things are unclear Ask friends for help Sit at the front of the classroom Take notes in class Finish assignments a day or two early to leave time to ask questions Use online math resources outside of course resources Practice a little bit every day Seek help from a tutor Use the calculator you will be using on tests when practicing Practice pre-requisite basic concepts (one topic at a time) Be sure to download our [LINK: https://successportal.conestogac.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/157] as well to help you stay on track. Math test-taking strategies Not sure how to study for a math test or exam? Are your current math study habits not working as they did in high school? This [LINK: http://wolczuk.com/es.html] discusses how to study effectively for math tests and exams. You can also save or print this [LINK: https://successportal.conestogac.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/93] to look back on while you're studying. More test-taking tips: [LINK: https://tlp-lpa.ca/math/preparing-for-tests] [LINK: https://tlp-lpa.ca/math/preparing-for-tests] Featured Event [LINK: /students/events/Detail/5266298/conestoga-consent-culture-byst] This workshop provides participants with a foundational knowledge of what sexual violence is and discusses what effective bystander intervention looks like. There will be an opportunity to explore how you can intervene, and what the effects are of different intervention tactics. Related Topics [LINK: /students/Resources/Topic/28] [LINK: /students/Resources/Topic/29] [LINK: /students/Resources/Topic/41] × Feedback Comments Send Feedback Close

Starting your term off right for math success Save Send Feedback [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/1470047] Things pick up quickly once the semester gets going. It is important to start the semester on the right foot and prepare yourself. Check out the tips below to help you start your math course with the right mindset. Get math help early Math builds on itself. Likely, what you learn in the first lesson of your math class will be needed throughout the course. Reach out to your instructor or book a math help appointment as soon as you are: Confused about a topic you learned in class. Stuck on a math practice problem. Preparing for a math test, quiz, etc. Remember, Conestoga provides [LINK: https://successportal.conestogac.on.ca/s/math] for eligible students. Follow your instructional plan Your instructional plan will give you an overview of the topics to be covered in your math course. Set aside some time to check over the plan before your class, so you know what topics will be covered. Even if these topics are new to you, it’s good to prepare yourself for what will come next. Don't skip the first class The first class is when the instructor explains the overview of the course, what their expectations are for students and what students can expect from the instructor. You will benefit from attending this first class for many reasons, including: Getting an overview of the course in a nutshell. Receiving information on free college resources (like math help!). Learning where to locate textbooks and class materials. Experiencing the first lesson. Meeting others in the class. Meeting your instructor. Learning the instructor's office hours. Explore your eConestoga course shell Every math class is different. It’s important to explore your eConestoga course shell for class notes, instructor announcements, and extra resources you may need during the course. Here are some things to explore in the course shell during the first week of classes: Location of class notes. Format of class notes (printable slides, videos, etc.). Calculator requirements. Pearson MyLab or Lyryx log in (if your instructor uses it). Online textbooks. Math help appointment booking instructions. Does your class use Pearson MyLab? The Study Plan feature is a great tool for extra practice and tracking progress. This [LINK: https://successportal.conestogac.on.ca/students/videos/detail/12] walks you through how to use the Study Plan feature. Explore math resources outside of class There are many free, useful math resources available outside of the classroom, from graphing technology to interactive mini-lessons. We recommend exploring our list of [LINK: https://successportal.conestogac.on.ca/students/infopages/detail/10] and that you save the [LINK: https://successportal.conestogac.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/90] in your notebook or on your bulletin board at home! Related Topics [LINK: /students/Resources/Topic/40] [LINK: /students/Resources/Topic/41] [LINK: /students/Resources/Topic/42] × Feedback Comments Send Feedback Close

Math technology Save Send Feedback [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/1470124] [LINK: https://www.desmos.com/calculator] [LINK: https://www.wolframalpha.com/] is a free math calculation tool. It can solve a variety of math problems, from simple addition to integration. Assistive and Learning Technologies services at Conestoga provide [LINK: https://lib.conestogac.on.ca/assistive-technology/math] for students to make math learning easier. Examples include math screen readers and math equation editors. You can [LINK: https://successportal.conestogac.on.ca/s/assistive-technology] if you would like assistance or more information on these resources. Contact – Student Success Portal For assistance with services on the Student Success Portal , please visit the specific service site from the HOME landing page. Each service will have unique contact information and methods that you can use to reach the service directly with your questions.

Conestoga College collects personal information from students under the legal authority of the Ontario Colleges of Applied Arts and Technology Act and ensures the personal information is managed in compliance with the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act in order offer students a comprehensive program of career-oriented, post-secondary education and training. The purpose of the Student Success Portal is to provide students with one shared system that enables students to self-book appointments with a variety of service teams at the College. As such, service teams will create consultation notes for students to review. These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way. Students participating in Events & Activities are acknowledging the sharing of their information for the purposes of tracking booking, attendance and follow-up activities by college services and opportunity providers. Conestoga protects personal information and only discloses it as required by law. If you have any questions, please reach out to [LINK: mailto:privacy@conestogac.on.ca] . By accepting these terms, you consent to the Student Success Portal and the information sharing provisions within it.

Contact – Student Success Portal For assistance with services on the Student Success Portal , please visit the specific service site from the HOME landing page. Each service will have unique contact information and methods that you can use to reach the service directly with your questions.

Conestoga College collects personal information from students under the legal authority of the Ontario Colleges of Applied Arts and Technology Act and ensures the personal information is managed in compliance with the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act in order offer students a comprehensive program of career-oriented, post-secondary education and training. The purpose of the Student Success Portal is to provide students with one shared system that enables students to self-book appointments with a variety of service teams at the College. As such, service teams will create consultation notes for students to review. These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way. Students participating in Events & Activities are acknowledging the sharing of their information for the purposes of tracking booking, attendance and follow-up activities by college services and opportunity providers. Conestoga protects personal information and only discloses it as required by law. If you have any questions, please reach out to [LINK: mailto:privacy@conestogac.on.ca] . By accepting these terms, you consent to the Student Success Portal and the information sharing provisions within it.

Contact – Student Success Portal For assistance with services on the Student Success Portal , please visit the specific service site from the HOME landing page. Each service will have unique contact information and methods that you can use to reach the service directly with your questions.

Conestoga College collects personal information from students under the legal authority of the Ontario Colleges of Applied Arts and Technology Act and ensures the personal information is managed in compliance with the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act in order offer students a comprehensive program of career-oriented, post-secondary education and training. The purpose of the Student Success Portal is to provide students with one shared system that enables students to self-book appointments with a variety of service teams at the College. As such, service teams will create consultation notes for students to review. These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way. Students participating in Events & Activities are acknowledging the sharing of their information for the purposes of tracking booking, attendance and follow-up activities by college services and opportunity providers. Conestoga protects personal information and only discloses it as required by law. If you have any questions, please reach out to [LINK: mailto:privacy@conestogac.on.ca] . By accepting these terms, you consent to the Student Success Portal and the information sharing provisions within it.
